He played most of his career for [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]] making 647 appearances for the club. He won the [[1975 FA Cup Final|1975 FA Cup]] and the [[1980 FA Cup Final|1980 FA Cup]] in which he scored the only goal. He was also the club's [[West Ham United F.C.#Hammer of the Year|player of the season]] on four occasions and caretaker manager on two occasions in 2003. Brooking played 47 times for [[England national football team|England]], scoring five times. He was appointed a [[Member of the Order of the British Empire]] (MBE) in 1981, elevated to [[Member of the Order of the British Empire|Commander]] of same order (CBE) in 1999, and [[Knight Bachelor|knighted]] in 2004. In 2009 a stand at [[Boleyn Ground|Upton Park]] was named after Brooking. Since retiring from playing, he has taken up a number of positions in broadcasting as an on-air analyst and in football and sports administration. ==Club career== ===West Ham United=== Brooking was born in [[Barking, London|Barking]] maternity hospital to mother Margaret and father, Henry Charles (known as Harry), who was a police officer in the [[Metropolitan Police]].{{harvnb|Brooking|2014|p=12}} Brooking attended Ripple Infants School and left [[Ilford County High School]] with 11 [[GCE Ordinary Level|O-level]]s and 2 [[GCE Advanced Level (United Kingdom)|A-levels]].{{cite book |last=Brooking |first=Trevor |title=Trevor Brooking |publisher=Pelham Books |year=1981 |isbn=0-7207-1374-9}} His father took him to see his first [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]] game at [[Boleyn Ground|Upton Park]], a 1–1 draw against [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] on 19 April 1958, when he was nine years old.{{cite web |title=Game played on 19 Apr 1958 |url=http://www.westhamstats.info/westham.php?west=5&ham=2094&united=19_Apr_1958 |publisher=www.westhamstats.info |accessdate=17 September 2012}} Aged fifteen he trained at both [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham]] and [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]].{{harvnb|Brooking|2014|p=17}} However West Ham manager, [[Ron Greenwood]] watched him with scout [[Wally St Pier]], and Brooking was offered apprenticeships by all three clubs with only West Ham allowing him to stay on at school to finish his studies. Despite his parents being offered £500 and a car by manager [[Tommy Docherty]] to gain his signature for Chelsea he remained at school signing an apprenticeship deal with West Ham on 24 July 1965, his parents receiving no fee. Brooking made his debut in place of wide-right [[Brian Dear]] on 29 August 1967 in a 3–3 draw with [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]] at [[Turf Moor]].{{harvnb|Brooking|2014|p=31}} His first goal came on 26 December 1967 in a 4–2 away win at [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]].{{cite web |title=Welcome to the Wonderful World of West Ham United Statistics Trevor Brooking |url=http://www.westhamstats.info/westham.php?west=2&ham=85&united=Trevor_Brooking |publisher=www.westhamstats.info |accessdate=17 September 2012}} His first season saw him play 28 games, scoring nine goals. His second season saw 37 appearances and eight goals. His only [[hat-trick]] came on 6 April 1968 in a 5–0 home defeat of [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle]]. During his third season, in December 1969 Brooking chipped a bone in his ankle in a game against [[Nottingham Forest F.C.|Nottingham Forest]].{{harvnb|Brooking|2014|p=39}} The club signed [[Peter Eustace]] for £90,000 to take his place; his recovery took longer than expected and he considered giving up the game. However he returned to playing and with the departure of [[Martin Peters]] to Tottenham in March 1970, Brooking became a regular in midfield. His place in the side came under threat in the 1971–72 season with the purchase of midfielder [[Tommy Taylor (footballer born 1951)|Tommy Taylor]], and Brooking was transfer-listed at his own request.{{harvnb|Brooking|2014|p=45}} However the failure of the defensive partnership between [[Bobby Moore]] and [[Alan Stephenson]] saw Stephenson dropped and Taylor being moved into defence; Brooking remained an ever-present for the rest of the season and was voted [[West Ham United F.C.#Hammer of the Year|Hammer of the Year]].{{harvnb|Brooking|2014|p=46}} During the 1972–73 season he came to the attention of [[Derby County F.C.|Derby County]] manager [[Brian Clough]], who offered West Ham £400,000 for Brooking and Moore, but Greenwood refused to let the pair leave.{{harvnb|Brooking|2014|p=47}} Again, in 1974 Tottenham manager [[Bill Nicholson (footballer)|Bill Nicholson]] offered £425,000 for the signature of Brooking. According to Brooking in his autobiography, this move was not pursued as he felt Nicholson, a manager he admired, was coming to the end of his Tottenham career and he was unsure of which manager would follow him. He won the [[FA Cup]] twice, in [[1975 FA Cup Final|1975]]{{cite web |title=1975 West Ham v Fulham |url=http://www.thefa.com/Competitions/FACompetitions/TheFACup/History/historyofthefacup/1975westhamfulham |archive-url=https://wayback.archive-it.org/all/20120428152821/http://www.thefa.com/Competitions/FACompetitions/TheFACup/History/HistoryOfTheFACup/1975WestHamFulham |dead-url=yes |archivedate=28 April 2012 |publisher=www.thefa.com |accessdate=17 September 2012 |df=dmy-all }} with Brooking scoring a vital goal in a 2–1 win in a 4th round replay away at [[Swindon Town F.C.|Swindon Town]]{{cite web |title=Game played on 28 Jan 1975 |url=http://www.westhamstats.info/westham.php?west=5&ham=2911&united=28_Jan_1975 |publisher=www.westhamstats.info |accessdate=17 September 2012}} and [[1980 FA Cup Final|1980]]; in the latter, he scored another vital goal in a 2–1 win in a third round replay against [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]]{{cite web |title=Game played on 08 Jan 1980 |url=http://www.westhamstats.info/westham.php?west=5&ham=3158&united=08_Jan_1980 |publisher=www.westhamstats.info |accessdate=17 September 2012}} and the only goal in a 1–0 win over [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] in the final with a header.{{cite web|title=FA Cup Final hero: Sir Trevor Brooking |url=http://www.whufc.com/articles/20060513/fa-cup-final-hero-sir-trevor-brooking_2236884_1141136 |publisher=www.whufc.com |accessdate=23 June 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150217203349/http://www.whufc.com/articles/20060513/fa-cup-final-hero-sir-trevor-brooking_2236884_1141136 |archivedate=17 February 2015 |df=dmy }} Brooking was a member of the West Ham team which won the [[1980–81 West Ham United F.C. season|Second Division in 1981]]. He also appeared in the [[1975 FA Charity Shield]], the [[1976 European Cup Winners' Cup Final]], the [[1980 FA Charity Shield]] and the [[1981 Football League Cup Final]]. His last game for West Ham came on 18 May 1984 in 1–0 home defeat by [[Everton F.C.|Everton]]. In total he made 647 appearances and scoring 102 times, wearing the number 10 jersey, his total appearances for West Ham only beaten by [[Billy Bonds]], [[Bobby Moore]] and [[Frank Lampard, Sr.|Frank Lampard]] Sr. He had a [[testimonial match]] against an England XI in October 1977.{{harvnb|Brooking|2014|p=53}} ===Later career=== Brooking accepted an invitation to play for [[Newcastle Blue Star F.C.|Blue Star]] in a Wearside League game against [[Coundon TT F.C.|Coundon]] on 28 April 1985. Blue Star had paid for him to fly to Newcastle as their guest and reportedly paid him an appearance fee of £500.{{cite web |url=http://northernleagueday.wordpress.com/2011/03/03/why-the-northern-league-matters-to-me-1/ |title=Why the Northern League matters to me |publisher=NorthernLeagueToday |date=2011-03-03 |accessdate=2013-06-10}} In 1985 Brooking played briefly for [[Cork City F.C.|Cork City]] making two appearances.{{cite web |title=Cork City — History |url=http://www.corkcityfc.net/home/club-info/history/ |publisher=www.corkcityfc.net |accessdate=24 September 2012}}{{cite web |title=Sir Trevor Brooking Opens John Lyall Pavilion |url=http://fcbusiness.co.uk/news/article/newsitem=1481/title=sir+trevor+brooking+opens+john+lyall+pavilion |publisher=www.fcbusiness.co.uk |accessdate=24 September 2012 |date=20 October 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121013231051/http://fcbusiness.co.uk/news/article/newsitem=1481/title=sir+trevor+brooking+opens+john+lyall+pavilion |archivedate=13 October 2012 |df=dmy-all }} ==International career== Brooking made his [[England national football team|England]] debut on 3 April 1974 in a 0–0 draw against [[Portugal national football team|Portugal]].{{cite web |title=Trevor Brooking — England |url=http://www.sporting-heroes.net/football/england/trevor-brooking-10956/english-caps-part-1-1974-78_a11103/ |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130222125910/http://www.sporting-heroes.net/football/england/trevor-brooking-10956/english-caps-part-1-1974-78_a11103/ |dead-url=yes |archivedate=22 February 2013 |publisher=www.sporting-heroes.net |accessdate=23 June 2012}} He played 47 times, scoring 5 goals but only appeared twice in major tournaments. At [[UEFA Euro 1980|Euro 1980]] in Italy he played in England's opening game against [[Belgium national football team|Belgium]] which was a 1–1 draw, but was dropped for the second game against [[Italy national football team|Italy]] which England lost 1–0. Re-instated to the starting eleven against [[Spain national football team|Spain]] he scored England's first goal in a 2–1 win.{{cite web |title=England match details 1980-1984 |url=http://www.englandfc.com/nostal/yrbyyr/1980_1984.html |publisher=www.englandfc.com |accessdate=23 June 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130927231019/http://www.englandfc.com/nostal/yrbyyr/1980_1984.html |archivedate=27 September 2013 |df=dmy-all }} Due to injury [[1982 FIFA World Cup|World Cup 1982]] was to see him limited to playing as a [[Substitute (association football)|substitute]] against Spain on 5 July 1982. Playing for only the last half-hour of the game, Brooking forced one excellent save from the Spanish goalkeeper, [[Luis Arconada]], but with England needing to win to qualify for the semi-final a 0-0 draw saw them eliminated. This was to be his final international appearance.{{cite web |title=Trevor Brooking |url=http://www.thefa.com/England/All-Teams/Players/B/Trevor-Brooking |publisher=Www.thefa.com |accessdate=18 May 2013}} ==Style of play== Brooking was primarily right-footed, but was comfortable on his left foot. He played as an attacking midfield player, known for his controlled passing and midfield authority.{{cite web |title=Diamonds Aren't Forever |url=http://www.thesportcollective.com/diamonds-arent-forever-joe-cole-england-liverpool-chelsea-west-ham/2011/06/ |publisher=www.thesportcollective.com |accessdate=24 September 2012}} Early in his career he was vulnerable to being out-muscled by opposition players (leading his teammates to nickname him 'Cyril' after [[Cyril Lord]] the carpet salesman, as [[Ron Greenwood]] told him "you're always on the floor").{{harvnb|Brooking|2014|p=40}} He lacked pace, leading to another nickname, Boog, after a slow [[baseball]] player called [[Boog Powell]] the team had witnessed during a tour of the USA.{{harvnb|Brooking|2014|p=41}} He was rarely booked or sent off during his West Ham career and due to his gentlemanly approach to the game where he rarely contested a referee's decision he picked up another nickname, [[Hadleigh (TV series)|Hadleigh]], after a television [[upper class]] and urbane detective played by [[Gerald Harper]].{{cite news |last=Coe |first=Sebastian |title=Government programme for sport delivered by Lottery |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/3035967/Government-programme-for-sport-delivered-by-Lottery.html# |accessdate=17 September 2012 |newspaper=www.dailytelegraph.co.uk |date=12 October 2002}} ==Managerial career== In April 2003, after West Ham manager [[Glenn Roeder]] collapsed due to a [[Brain tumor|brain tumour]], Brooking, having long been on the board at West Ham, briefly took over as caretaker manager. The club were fighting relegation from the [[Premier League]]. Brooking took charge of three games. His first game resulted in a 1–0 away win at [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]] with a goal from [[Frédéric Kanouté]].{{cite news |last=Taylor |first=Daniel |title=Kanoute injects fresh hope into West Ham |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2003/apr/28/match.manchestercity |accessdate=18 September 2012 |newspaper=www.guardian.co.uk |date=28 April 2003}} His second saw West Ham beat [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] 1–0, thanks to a goal from [[Paolo Di Canio]].{{cite news |title=Di Canio grabs West Ham lifeline |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/2968013.stm |accessdate=18 September 2012 |newspaper=BBC Sport}} The final game of the season saw West Ham draw 2–2 away at [[Birmingham City F.C.|Birmingham City]] resulting in relegation,{{cite news |title=West Ham relegated |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/2978071.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=18 September 2012}} albeit with 42 points, a record number for a relegated team.{{cite news |last=Wilson |first=Jeremy |title='Survival Sunday' looms in what promises to be one of the tightest Premier League relegation battles ever |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/competitions/premier-league/8362912/Survival-Sunday-looms-in-what-promises-to-be-one-of-the-tightest-Premier-League-relegation-battles-ever.html |accessdate=12 August 2011 |newspaper=www.telegraph.co.uk |date=4 March 2011}} After the first three games of the [[2003–04 in English football|2003/2004 season]] with West Ham now in the [[Football League First Division|First Division]], Roeder was sacked after West Ham suffered an away defeat to [[Rotherham United F.C.|Rotherham United]]{{cite news |title=Roeder sacking inevitable |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/w/west_ham_utd/3178205.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=17 September 2012}} and Brooking was again installed as caretaker manager. He managed for eleven games, losing only once, to [[Gillingham F.C.|Gillingham]], a 2–0 away defeat in which [[Jermain Defoe]] was sent-off.{{cite news |title=Gillingham 2-0 West Ham |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_1/3109594.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=17 September 2012}} In October 2003 he was replaced by [[Alan Pardew]], who was appointed on his recommendation.{{harvnb|Brooking|2014|p=7}} ==Media career== In 1984, Brooking joined the [[BBC]] as a pundit, and has featured on radio and television commentary since, including the BBC's ''[[Match of the Day]]'' and coverage of [[FIFA World Cup|World Cup]]s and [[UEFA European Football Championship|European Championships]]. He was also the co-commentator in the ''[[Pro Evolution Soccer]]'' video game series, alongside [[Peter Brackley]] until ''[[Pro Evolution Soccer 6]]''. ==Football administration== Brooking was Chair of the Eastern Region Council for Sport and Recreation from 1987 until 1997, and between 1999 and 2002 he was chairman of [[Sport England]].{{harvnb|Brooking|2014|p=1}} In January 2004, he joined [[the Football Association]] as Director of Football Development, a role which gave him total of control of coaching and development in English football, as well as a role in appointing future [[England national football team|England]] managers.{{harvnb|Brooking|2014|p=3}} He was a key part of the selection process for the successor of the [[Sven-Göran Eriksson]], revealed in May 2006 to be [[Steve McClaren]]. In 2004, he was [[Knight Bachelor|knighted]] for his services to sport.{{London Gazette|issue=57315 |supp=y|page=1|date=12 June 2004}} ==Personal life== In June 1970, he married Hilkka, a [[Finnish people|Finnish]] [[au pair]].{{harvnb|Brooking|2014|p=36}} The couple have two children: Collette and Warren.{{harvnb|Brooking|2014|p=37}} In 1970, along with schoolfriend Colin McGowan, Brooking started a [[book binding]] company, Colbrook Plastics Limited (now Colbrook Binding Limited), in [[Basildon]], [[Essex]]. He was awarded an honorary doctorate from the [[University of Essex]] in 2001.{{cite web|title=University of Essex Calendar |url=http://www.essex.ac.uk/academic/docs/cal/former.shtm |publisher=www.essex.ac.uk |accessdate=23 June 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121007233550/http://www.essex.ac.uk/academic/docs/cal/former.shtm |archivedate=7 October 2012 |df=dmy }} In October 2014, his autobiography, ''Trevor Brooking, My Life in Football'', was published.{{cite news |last1=Shales |first1=Mark |title=West Ham legend Trevor Brooking signs autobiographies at Newham Bookshop |url=http://www.newhamrecorder.co.uk/news/west_ham_legend_trevor_brooking_signs_autobiographies_at_newham_bookshop_1_3797728 |accessdate=17 February 2015 In 2009 in a [[2009 Upton Park riot|match between West Ham and Millwall]] seats were torn out by Millwall fans and hurled towards West Ham fans.{{cite news|title=West Ham and Millwall charged over crowd trouble |url=http://www.wharf.co.uk/2009/09/west-ham-and-millwall-charged.html |accessdate=25 September 2012 |newspaper=www.wharf.co.uk |date=28 September 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141227092224/http://www.wharf.co.uk/2009/09/west-ham-and-millwall-charged.html |archivedate=27 December 2014 |df=dmy }} In subsequent seasons, Millwall fans were segregated to the upper tier of the stand and kept at least 30 yards from West Ham fans to prevent crowd disturbances.{{cite news |last=Walters |first=Mike |title=West Ham vs Millwall goes into lockdown |url=http://www.mirrorfootball.co.uk/news/West-Ham-v-Millwall-match-sees-massive-security-operation-to-prevent-repeat-of-2009-riot-article861002.html |accessdate=25 September 2012 |newspaper=www.dailymirror.co.uk |date=3 February 2012}} A stand at the [[Olympic Stadium (London)|Olympic Stadium]] is also named after Brooking and used by West Ham after their move from the Boleyn Ground from the start of the 2016–17 season.{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/west-ham/9962213/West-Ham-United-reveal-further-plans-for-Olympic-Stadium-redevelopment.html |title=West Ham United reveal further plans for Olympic Stadium redevelopment |work=The Telegraph |date=29 March 2013 |accessdate=27 December 2014}} {{Quote box| width=50% |align=center |quote=It is obviously a terrific honour (to have the stand named after me), which I am very grateful for because this is my club. It will be my club forever. The great thing was being able to spend my whole career with West Ham, having a stint as caretaker manager and as a director. I still try and get to most of the home games. On my travels, if I am in a cab or something then everyone talks to me about West Ham because they know I am associated with the club. It is something I am only too pleased about whenever it happens.
